news.title: FIFA bans Highlanders from signing players
news.content:
Story by Mthokozisi Dube
Bulawayo giants, Highlanders Football Club’s preparations for the 2025 season have been dealt a huge blow after the world football governing body, FIFA handed the club a transfer ban over unpaid salaries to their former gaffer Baltemer Brito.
Less than a month ago, the club appeared to be on top of the situation in settling the salary arrears owed to their former coach Portuguese, Baltermer Brito and his assistant Antonio Torres.
The club made its stakeholders believe that their principal sponsor Sakunda holdings was making plans to settle the debt.
Brito is owed US$15 000 while Antonio is owed close to US$12 000 in salary and bonus arears.

news.title: Warriors to play two Group B matches in Morocco
news.content:
Story by Mthokozisi Dube
The Zimbabwe senior men’s football team, the Warriors, will play two of their Group B matches at the Stade de Marrakech in Morocco after the Confederation of African Football (CAF) released the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations schedule.
The Michael Nees-mentored side begin duty on Unity Day with a tricky encounter against African giants Egypt set for the 45 000-seater Stade d’Agadir on the shore of the Atlantic Ocean near the Atlas Mountains.
Four days later, the Warriors shift base for their second match against Angola set for the Stade de Marrakech.
The Warriors will wind-up their Group B campaign with a battle against South Africa’s Bafana Bafana at the same venue.

news.title: Mash Central braces for NASH tourney
news.content:
Story by Tapiwa Machemedze
MASHONALAND Central Province is preparing to host the National Association of Secondary Heads (NASH) competitions, with the construction of the main stadium for the event near completion.
NASH competitions is one of the biggest events on the schools’ calendar running from the 1st to the 4th of April and Chipadze High School will host the games with preparations already advanced.

news.title: Newly elected ZIFA board challenged to prioritise player welfare
news.content:
Story by Lawrence Trusida, Sport Editor
THE newly-elected Zimbabwe Football Association (ZIFA) Executive committee has pledged to uphold integrity and turnaround the sport in the country.
The new football leadership led by Nqobile Magwizi met with the Sport and Recreation Commission (SRC) in Harare this Thursday to share their vision and appraise them on the direction they are taking the country’s most followed sport.
The board, which was elected a fortnight ago, wasted no time in highlighting that they are committed to make the sport an envy for everyone, with upholding corporate governance set to be prioritised.
“We want to set up an institution that is transparent, accountable and open for everyone,” Magwizi said.
“Our hope is to create an institution that will last beyond our tenure and when anyone comes in they can continue and it shouldn’t be a shock that there is a new president and an institution that is judged on results on the pitch we need to make sure that we create a platform for our players to thrive from junior level up till the highest level.”
The SRC challenged the new board to prioritise player welfare.
“I know you are new and you still need to be known but very soon we want to see the players, the captains and the coaches, sport is about the athletes and they should be put at the front and your role is to make sure you provide a good platform for them to showcase their talents,” SRC chairperson, Gerald Mlotshwa said.

news.title: Chevrons brace for Irish test
news.content:
Story by Lawrence Trusida, Sport Editor
ZIMBABWE will be seeking to win their first test match against Ireland when the two teams clash in the only test match slated for Queen Sports Club starting this Thursday.
The Chevrons smarting from a test series loss to Afghanistan will be seeking to win their first test of this year when they face Ireland.
It is easier said than done especially with the way the Chevrons’ performances fluctuate.
On the odd day, they can be special but then sometimes they tend to be awful.
This Thursday they step onto the Queens Sports Club pitch in Bulawayo looking to beat the Irish in a test match for the first time.
The two sides met only once in the longest format and Ireland won that meeting last year.
The hosts go into the match seeking their first win in the last six tests, while Ireland have won two in the same period, and Zimbabwe also anchor the 12-team International Cricket Council test rankings.
The return to full fitness for veteran Sean Williams is a major boost to the Chevrons’ ambitions of winning their first test this year.
The all-rounder was an injury scare for the Chevrons after he struggled with back pains in the New Year’s Day Test match against Afghanistan.
